description: From French as if *amenable, from amener (“to bring or lead, fetch in or to”), from a- + mener (“to lead, conduct”), from Late Latin mināre (“to drive”), Latin deponent minārī (“to threaten, menace”).

adjectives.description: amenable (comparative more amenable, superlative most amenable)

entries.meaning: Willing to respond to persuasion or suggestions.
Liable to be brought to account, to a charge or claim; responsible; accountable; answerable.
(law) Liable to the legal authority of (something).
examples: decisions of the Boards of Appeal are amenable to actions before the Court of Justice of the European Communities

entries.meaning: (mathematics, of a group) Being a locally compact topological group carrying a kind of averaging operation on bounded functions that is invariant under translation by group elements.
